prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the story (the author) is in the wrong. The situation is about a husband working from home in their bedroom, causing disruptions for the author who also works and handles most of the childcare and chores.

First, the husband chose to set up his office in the bedroom despite being offered the basement, which is quieter. The main issue is that when he's on calls, the author can't use the top floor, including the bathroom and doing chores. The author is taking on a lot of responsibilities and is being restricted by the husband's setup.

The husband's choice to work in the bedroom might be about his comfort (better view), but it's causing practical problems for the author. The author isn't being asked to be completely quiet, just to avoid disturbances during his calls. But since the office is in their shared bedroom, it's a space that's naturally used by both, so maybe the husband's decision is the root of the problem.

The author is saying she can't work or manage chores, and even basic things like showering or using the bathroom are restricted. The husband is working from home, which is a valid need, but he might not be considering the impact on his wife's daily life. The author is standing her ground by suggesting the basement, which is more suitable for an office and allows her to function without disruptions.

Considering work-life balance and shared responsibilities, the husband's insistence on being in the bedroom office is creating an imbalance. The author isn't at fault for not being able to guarantee silence when he's in a shared space. So, the answer is likely B (the author is not in the wrong).
